description: From Latin intimare (“to put or bring into, to impress, to make familiar”), from intimus (“inmost, innermost, most intimate”), superlative of intus (“within”), from in (“in”); see interior.

adjectives.description: intimate (comparative more intimate, superlative most intimate)

examples: He and his sister deeply valued their intimate relationship as they didn't have much else to live for.

entries.meaning: Of or involved in a sexual relationship.
examples: She enjoyed some intimate time alone with her husband.

entries.meaning: Pertaining to details that require great familiarity to know.

examples: Black powder consists of an intimate mixture of potassium nitrate, charcoal, and sulfur.
Only a couple of intimates had ever read his writing.

entries.meaning: (in plural intimates) Women's underwear, sleepwear, or lingerie, especially offered for sale in a store.
examples: You'll find bras and panties in the women's intimates section upstairs.

verbs.description: intimate (third-person singular simple present intimates, present participle intimating, simple past and past participle intimated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To suggest or disclose (something) discreetly.
examples: The Kaiser beamed. Von Bulow had praised him. Von Bulow had exalted him and humbled himself. The Kaiser could forgive anything after that. "Haven't I always told you," he exclaimed with enthusiasm, "that we complete one another famously? We should stick together, and we will!"     [...]     Von Bulow saved himself in time—but, canny diplomat that he was, he nevertheless had made one error: he should have begun by talking about his own shortcomings and Wilhelm's superiority—not by intimating that the Kaiser was a half-wit in need of a guardian.
I will intimate you when the details are available.
